definitions.definition: a business organization that makes money by producing or selling goods or services

examples.text: **insurance/oil/tech/technology/pharmaceutical companies**
It is the world's largest **software company**.
He works for the National Bus Company.
Carrington **and Company** of London
a **large/small company**
She **runs** her own TV production **company**.
to **own/start/found a company**
The company has/have just announced record profits.
Smoking in the workplace is against **company policy**.
Company profits were 5 per cent lower than last year.
a **company executive/director**
a company pension
During the recession many small companies went out of business.
He has shares in several companies.
She's been working for the same company for 15 years.
The company has been taken over by a rival.
The company produces cotton goods.
a major European company
a small insurance company
a small start-up software company
an international trading company
the division of power within a company
It is company policy not to allow smoking in the building.
Mike gets a company car with his new job.
She joined the company in 2009.
During the 1980s it was one of the largest computer companies in the world.
This new car has been developed with parent company Toyota.

definitions.definition: a group of people who work or perform together

examples.text: a theatre/dance company
the Royal Shakespeare Company
a small touring opera company
The company has/have just been on tour.

definitions.definition: the fact of being with somebody else and not alone
definitions.sensetop: somebody's companyin the company of somebodyfor company

examples.text: I enjoy Jo's company *(= I enjoy being with her)*.
a pleasant evening in the company of friends
She enjoys **her own company** *(= being by herself)* when she is travelling.
The children are very **good company** *(= pleasant to be with)* at this age.
He's coming with me for company.
He's nervous in the company of his colleagues.
He's very good company.
I always enjoy her company.
I took my mother with me for company.
It's nice to have a bit of company for a change.

phrases: have the pleasure of somebody’s company
request the pleasure of somebody’s company

examples.text: I didn't realize you **had company**.
We're expecting company this afternoon.
The dining room was only used when they had company.
She told the assembled company what had happened.
It is bad manners to whisper in company *(= in a group of people)*.
Those children don't know how to behave in company.
He glanced around the assembled company.
It's not the type of joke you'd tell in mixed company (= in a group of people of both sexes).

definitions.definition: a group of soldiers that is part of a battalion
the people that somebody spends time with

examples.text: Judging by the company he kept, Mark must have been a wealthy man.
Jane's mother was worried about the company she kept.

definitions.definition: to be friends with people that others think are bad

examples.text: They worried about their teenage son getting into bad company.
She got into bad company and got involved in crime.

definitions.definition: together with or at the same time as somebody/something

examples.text: She arrived in company with the ship's captain.
The US dollar went through a difficult time, in company with the oil market.

definitions.definition: if you say that somebody is in good company, you mean that they should not worry about a mistake, etc. because somebody else, especially somebody more important, has done the same thing

examples.text: If you worry about your relationship with your teenage son or daughter, you are in good company. Many parents share these worries.

definitions.definition: to stay with somebody so that they are not alone

examples.text: I'll keep you company while you're waiting.
I'll stay and keep you company.

definitions.definition: to leave somebody; to end a relationship with somebody

examples.text: This is where we part company *(= go in different directions)*.
The band have parted company with their manager.
The band and their manager have parted company.
He parted ways with the team at the end of the season.

definitions.definition: to disagree with somebody about something

examples.text: Weber parted company with Marx on a number of important issues.
The two leaders parted ways on this question.

definitions.definition: used after being rude or critical about somebody to say that the people you are talking to are not included in the criticism

examples.text: The people in this office are so narrow-minded, present company excepted, of course.

definitions.definition: used to suggest that it is better to be in a group of only two people than have a third person with you as well

wordOrigin: Middle English (in senses (2) to (6)): from Old French compainie; related to compaignon, literally ‘one who breaks bread with another’, based on Latin com- ‘together with’ + panis ‘bread’.
